user_error_text: No Valid IP Configuration — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: No Valid IP Configuration. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: No Valid IP Configuration - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'WAN port unplugged' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: WAN port unplugged. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).
step_5: Update router firmware from the vendor's official site if available.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: WAN port unplugged - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Antivirus blocking network' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Antivirus blocking network. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Antivirus blocking network - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'IP conflict detected' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: IP conflict detected. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: IP conflict detected - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps.
symptoms: Network issue: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Ethernet (LAN Cable) Connection Errors.
cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.
step_1: Ensure Ethernet cable is securely plugged in and test with a different cable.
step_2: Try a different LAN port on the router/switch to rule out port failure.
step_3: Check adapter link speed in Network Connections and set to auto-negotiate.
step_4: Update NIC drivers and disable energy-saving features that may drop the link.
step_5: Test the cable with another device to confirm the cable is not faulty.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading
user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: ERR_CONNECTION_TIMED_OUT.
symptoms: Network issue: ERR_CONNECTION_TIMED_OUT. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading.
cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.
step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.
step_3: Ping a website (ping google.com) to test connectivity and traceroute to identify block points.
step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.
step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: ERR_CONNECTION_TIMED_OUT - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Proxy server error. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Proxy server error. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Proxy server error - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Interference causing speed drops — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Interference causing speed drops. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Slow Internet / Low Bandwidth Issues.
cause: Bandwidth congestion, ISP throttling, interference, or hardware limits.
step_1: Run an internet speed test (speedtest.net) to measure download/upload and ping.
step_2: Restart router and modem, and disconnect any heavy-usage devices.
step_3: Move closer to Wi‑Fi or use Ethernet to check if wireless is the bottleneck.
step_4: Check for scheduled tasks or background updates using Task Manager that may consume bandwidth.
step_5: If ISP throttling suspected, contact ISP or try VPN to compare speeds.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Interference causing speed drops - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

symptoms: Network issue: Router not broadcasting Wi-Fi. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.

user_error_text: I get 'Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_BAD_CONFIG — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_BAD_CONFIG. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: DNS (Domain Name System) Errors.
cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.
step_2: Set DNS manually to Google DNS (8.8.8.8 / 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) and retry.
step_3: Restart your router to refresh DNS settings from ISP.
step_4: Check if other devices can resolve websites to isolate device vs network DNS issue.
step_5: If DNS server is provided by ISP and failing, contact ISP for resolution.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_BAD_CONFIG - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Driver corrupted or outdated. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Driver corrupted or outdated. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Network Adapter / Driver Errors.
cause: Network adapter driver missing, corrupted, or device disabled in OS.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for the network adapter; enable it if disabled.
step_2: Right-click adapter → Uninstall device, then reboot to let Windows reinstall the driver.
step_3: Download the latest driver from the manufacturer and install it.
step_4: Check Windows Airplane mode toggle and make sure it's off.
step_5: If adapter missing, try using a USB Wi‑Fi dongle or external adapter to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Driver corrupted or outdated - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'Incorrect ISP configuration' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: Incorrect ISP configuration. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: ISP Outages & External Issues.
cause: External outage or service degradation from ISP side.
step_1: Check ISP outage map or contact ISP to confirm known outages in your area.
step_2: Restart the modem and router, and verify WAN/DSL lights are active.
step_3: If using fiber/DSL, check physical line connections and ONT status.
step_4: Use mobile data tethering to confirm whether local network or ISP is at fault.
step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Incorrect ISP configuration - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Interference causing speed drops - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: 169.254.x.x APIPA assigned. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: 169.254.x.x APIPA assigned. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: 169.254.x.x APIPA assigned - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Router not broadcasting Wi-Fi — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Router not broadcasting Wi-Fi. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).
step_5: Update router firmware from the vendor's official site if available.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Router not broadcasting Wi-Fi - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Wi-Fi keeps disconnecting - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'Proxy server error' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: Proxy server error. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Proxy server error - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'Code 10: This device cannot start' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: Code 10: This device cannot start. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Network Adapter / Driver Errors.
cause: Network adapter driver missing, corrupted, or device disabled in OS.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for the network adapter; enable it if disabled.
step_2: Right-click adapter → Uninstall device, then reboot to let Windows reinstall the driver.
step_3: Download the latest driver from the manufacturer and install it.
step_4: Check Windows Airplane mode toggle and make sure it's off.
step_5: If adapter missing, try using a USB Wi‑Fi dongle or external adapter to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Code 10: This device cannot start - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

symptoms: Network issue: Fiber/DSL line fault. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: ISP Outages & External Issues.
cause: External outage or service degradation from ISP side.
step_1: Check ISP outage map or contact ISP to confirm known outages in your area.
step_2: Restart the modem and router, and verify WAN/DSL lights are active.

step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Fiber/DSL line fault - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Slow Internet / Low Bandwidth Issues.
cause: Bandwidth congestion, ISP throttling, interference, or hardware limits.
step_1: Run an internet speed test (speedtest.net) to measure download/upload and ping.
step_2: Restart router and modem, and disconnect any heavy-usage devices.
step_3: Move closer to Wi‑Fi or use Ethernet to check if wireless is the bottleneck.
step_4: Check for scheduled tasks or background updates using Task Manager that may consume bandwidth.
step_5: If ISP throttling suspected, contact ISP or try VPN to compare speeds.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading

symptoms: Network issue: Connected but can't access websites. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading.
cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.
step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.
step_3: Ping a website (ping google.com) to test connectivity and traceroute to identify block points.
step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.
step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.

user_error_text: I get 'ERR_NAME_NOT_RESOLVED' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: ERR_NAME_NOT_RESOLVED. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: DNS (Domain Name System) Errors.
cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.
step_2: Set DNS manually to Google DNS (8.8.8.8 / 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) and retry.
step_3: Restart your router to refresh DNS settings from ISP.
step_4: Check if other devices can resolve websites to isolate device vs network DNS issue.
step_5: If DNS server is provided by ISP and failing, contact ISP for resolution.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: ERR_NAME_NOT_RESOLVED - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed.
symptoms: Network issue: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Slow Internet / Low Bandwidth Issues.
cause: Bandwidth congestion, ISP throttling, interference, or hardware limits.
step_1: Run an internet speed test (speedtest.net) to measure download/upload and ping.
step_2: Restart router and modem, and disconnect any heavy-usage devices.
step_3: Move closer to Wi‑Fi or use Ethernet to check if wireless is the bottleneck.
step_4: Check for scheduled tasks or background updates using Task Manager that may consume bandwidth.
step_5: If ISP throttling suspected, contact ISP or try VPN to compare speeds.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Antivirus blocking network — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Antivirus blocking network. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Antivirus blocking network - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: Network adapter missing.
symptoms: Network issue: Network adapter missing. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Network Adapter / Driver Errors.
cause: Network adapter driver missing, corrupted, or device disabled in OS.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for the network adapter; enable it if disabled.
step_2: Right-click adapter → Uninstall device, then reboot to let Windows reinstall the driver.
step_3: Download the latest driver from the manufacturer and install it.
step_4: Check Windows Airplane mode toggle and make sure it's off.
step_5: If adapter missing, try using a USB Wi‑Fi dongle or external adapter to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Network adapter missing - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

error_name: DNS address could not be found
user_error_text: My PC reports 'DNS address could not be found' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: DNS address could not be found. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: DNS (Domain Name System) Errors.
cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.
step_2: Set DNS manually to Google DNS (8.8.8.8 / 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) and retry.
step_3: Restart your router to refresh DNS settings from ISP.
step_4: Check if other devices can resolve websites to isolate device vs network DNS issue.
step_5: If DNS server is provided by ISP and failing, contact ISP for resolution.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: DNS address could not be found - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading
user_error_text: Connected but can't access websites — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Connected but can't access websites. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading.
cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.
step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.
step_3: Ping a website (ping google.com) to test connectivity and traceroute to identify block points.
step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.
step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Connected but can't access websites - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.

step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).

user_error_text: Weak Wi-Fi signal — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Weak Wi-Fi signal. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Weak Wi-Fi signal - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'Fiber/DSL line fault' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: Fiber/DSL line fault. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: ISP Outages & External Issues.
cause: External outage or service degradation from ISP side.
step_1: Check ISP outage map or contact ISP to confirm known outages in your area.
step_2: Restart the modem and router, and verify WAN/DSL lights are active.
step_3: If using fiber/DSL, check physical line connections and ONT status.
step_4: Use mobile data tethering to confirm whether local network or ISP is at fault.
step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Fiber/DSL line fault - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

symptoms: Network issue: IP conflict detected. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: IP conflict detected - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_NO_INTERNET' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_NO_INTERNET. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: DNS (Domain Name System) Errors.
cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.
step_2: Set DNS manually to Google DNS (8.8.8.8 / 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) and retry.
step_3: Restart your router to refresh DNS settings from ISP.
step_4: Check if other devices can resolve websites to isolate device vs network DNS issue.
step_5: If DNS server is provided by ISP and failing, contact ISP for resolution.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_NO_INTERNET - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Router not broadcasting Wi-Fi' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Router not broadcasting Wi-Fi. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).
step_5: Update router firmware from the vendor's official site if available.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Router not broadcasting Wi-Fi - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Poor signal from ISP' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Poor signal from ISP. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: ISP Outages & External Issues.
cause: External outage or service degradation from ISP side.
step_1: Check ISP outage map or contact ISP to confirm known outages in your area.
step_2: Restart the modem and router, and verify WAN/DSL lights are active.
step_3: If using fiber/DSL, check physical line connections and ONT status.
step_4: Use mobile data tethering to confirm whether local network or ISP is at fault.
step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Poor signal from ISP - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Unidentified network — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Unidentified network. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Ethernet (LAN Cable) Connection Errors.
cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.
step_1: Ensure Ethernet cable is securely plugged in and test with a different cable.
step_2: Try a different LAN port on the router/switch to rule out port failure.
step_3: Check adapter link speed in Network Connections and set to auto-negotiate.
step_4: Update NIC drivers and disable energy-saving features that may drop the link.
step_5: Test the cable with another device to confirm the cable is not faulty.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Unidentified network - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: IP conflict detected. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: IP conflict detected. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: IP conflict detected - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading
user_error_text: My PC reports 'SSL certificate errors' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: SSL certificate errors. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading.
cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.
step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.
step_3: Ping a website (ping google.com) to test connectivity and traceroute to identify block points.
step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.
step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: SSL certificate errors - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

symptoms: Network issue: ERR_CONNECTION_RESET. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading.
cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.
step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.
step_3: Ping a website (ping google.com) to test connectivity and traceroute to identify block points.
step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.

user_error_text: I get 'Can't connect to this network' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Can't connect to this network. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Can't connect to this network - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.

step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Firewall blocking internet access - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Poor signal from ISP — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Poor signal from ISP. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: ISP Outages & External Issues.
cause: External outage or service degradation from ISP side.
step_1: Check ISP outage map or contact ISP to confirm known outages in your area.
step_2: Restart the modem and router, and verify WAN/DSL lights are active.
step_3: If using fiber/DSL, check physical line connections and ONT status.
step_4: Use mobile data tethering to confirm whether local network or ISP is at fault.
step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Poor signal from ISP - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: ISP DHCP server issues — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: ISP DHCP server issues. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).
step_5: Update router firmware from the vendor's official site if available.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: ISP DHCP server issues - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: Router not giving IP.
symptoms: Network issue: Router not giving IP. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Router not giving IP - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Cable unplugged' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Cable unplugged. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Ethernet (LAN Cable) Connection Errors.
cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.
step_1: Ensure Ethernet cable is securely plugged in and test with a different cable.
step_2: Try a different LAN port on the router/switch to rule out port failure.
step_3: Check adapter link speed in Network Connections and set to auto-negotiate.
step_4: Update NIC drivers and disable energy-saving features that may drop the link.
step_5: Test the cable with another device to confirm the cable is not faulty.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Cable unplugged - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_NO_INTERNET' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_NO_INTERNET. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: DNS (Domain Name System) Errors.
cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.
step_2: Set DNS manually to Google DNS (8.8.8.8 / 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) and retry.
step_3: Restart your router to refresh DNS settings from ISP.
step_4: Check if other devices can resolve websites to isolate device vs network DNS issue.
step_5: If DNS server is provided by ISP and failing, contact ISP for resolution.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_NO_INTERNET - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'Cable unplugged' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: Cable unplugged. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Ethernet (LAN Cable) Connection Errors.
cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.
step_1: Ensure Ethernet cable is securely plugged in and test with a different cable.
step_2: Try a different LAN port on the router/switch to rule out port failure.
step_3: Check adapter link speed in Network Connections and set to auto-negotiate.
step_4: Update NIC drivers and disable energy-saving features that may drop the link.
step_5: Test the cable with another device to confirm the cable is not faulty.

log_snippet: Cable unplugged - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Weak Wi-Fi signal. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Weak Wi-Fi signal. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Weak Wi-Fi signal - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Airplane mode stuck ON' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Airplane mode stuck ON. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Network Adapter / Driver Errors.
cause: Network adapter driver missing, corrupted, or device disabled in OS.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for the network adapter; enable it if disabled.
step_2: Right-click adapter → Uninstall device, then reboot to let Windows reinstall the driver.
step_3: Download the latest driver from the manufacturer and install it.
step_4: Check Windows Airplane mode toggle and make sure it's off.
step_5: If adapter missing, try using a USB Wi‑Fi dongle or external adapter to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Airplane mode stuck ON - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading
user_error_text: Connected but can't access websites — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Connected but can't access websites. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading.
cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.
step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.
step_3: Ping a website (ping google.com) to test connectivity and traceroute to identify block points.
step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.
step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Connected but can't access websites - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Firewall blocking internet access' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Firewall blocking internet access. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Interference causing speed drops. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Interference causing speed drops. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Slow Internet / Low Bandwidth Issues.
cause: Bandwidth congestion, ISP throttling, interference, or hardware limits.
step_1: Run an internet speed test (speedtest.net) to measure download/upload and ping.
step_2: Restart router and modem, and disconnect any heavy-usage devices.
step_3: Move closer to Wi‑Fi or use Ethernet to check if wireless is the bottleneck.
step_4: Check for scheduled tasks or background updates using Task Manager that may consume bandwidth.
step_5: If ISP throttling suspected, contact ISP or try VPN to compare speeds.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Interference causing speed drops - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: SSL certificate errors - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'Bandwidth throttling' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: Bandwidth throttling. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Slow Internet / Low Bandwidth Issues.
cause: Bandwidth congestion, ISP throttling, interference, or hardware limits.
step_1: Run an internet speed test (speedtest.net) to measure download/upload and ping.
step_2: Restart router and modem, and disconnect any heavy-usage devices.
step_3: Move closer to Wi‑Fi or use Ethernet to check if wireless is the bottleneck.
step_4: Check for scheduled tasks or background updates using Task Manager that may consume bandwidth.
step_5: If ISP throttling suspected, contact ISP or try VPN to compare speeds.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Bandwidth throttling - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: ERR_TUNNEL_CONNECTION_FAILED — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: ERR_TUNNEL_CONNECTION_FAILED. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: ERR_TUNNEL_CONNECTION_FAILED - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

error_name: No internet due to ISP outage
user_error_text: Can't browse, error: No internet due to ISP outage. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: No internet due to ISP outage. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: ISP Outages & External Issues.
cause: External outage or service degradation from ISP side.
step_1: Check ISP outage map or contact ISP to confirm known outages in your area.
step_2: Restart the modem and router, and verify WAN/DSL lights are active.
step_3: If using fiber/DSL, check physical line connections and ONT status.
step_4: Use mobile data tethering to confirm whether local network or ISP is at fault.
step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: No internet due to ISP outage - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: VPN connected but no internet — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: VPN connected but no internet. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: VPN connected but no internet - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Weak Wi-Fi signal — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Weak Wi-Fi signal. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Weak Wi-Fi signal - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports '169.254.x.x APIPA assigned' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: 169.254.x.x APIPA assigned. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: 169.254.x.x APIPA assigned - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: DNS server not responding — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: DNS server not responding. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: DNS (Domain Name System) Errors.
cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.
step_2: Set DNS manually to Google DNS (8.8.8.8 / 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) and retry.
step_3: Restart your router to refresh DNS settings from ISP.
step_4: Check if other devices can resolve websites to isolate device vs network DNS issue.
step_5: If DNS server is provided by ISP and failing, contact ISP for resolution.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: DNS server not responding - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Can't connect to this network. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Can't connect to this network. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Can't connect to this network - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: Ethernet not connected.
symptoms: Network issue: Ethernet not connected. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Ethernet (LAN Cable) Connection Errors.
cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.
step_1: Ensure Ethernet cable is securely plugged in and test with a different cable.
step_2: Try a different LAN port on the router/switch to rule out port failure.
step_3: Check adapter link speed in Network Connections and set to auto-negotiate.
step_4: Update NIC drivers and disable energy-saving features that may drop the link.
step_5: Test the cable with another device to confirm the cable is not faulty.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Ethernet not connected - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading

cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Frequent router restarts. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Frequent router restarts. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).
step_5: Update router firmware from the vendor's official site if available.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Frequent router restarts - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

cause: Network adapter driver missing, corrupted, or device disabled in OS.

step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.
step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.

step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.

error_name: DNS address could not be found
user_error_text: My PC reports 'DNS address could not be found' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: DNS address could not be found. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: DNS (Domain Name System) Errors.
cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.
step_2: Set DNS manually to Google DNS (8.8.8.8 / 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) and retry.
step_3: Restart your router to refresh DNS settings from ISP.
step_4: Check if other devices can resolve websites to isolate device vs network DNS issue.
step_5: If DNS server is provided by ISP and failing, contact ISP for resolution.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: DNS address could not be found - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Ethernet (LAN Cable) Connection Errors.
cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.
step_1: Ensure Ethernet cable is securely plugged in and test with a different cable.
step_2: Try a different LAN port on the router/switch to rule out port failure.
step_3: Check adapter link speed in Network Connections and set to auto-negotiate.
step_4: Update NIC drivers and disable energy-saving features that may drop the link.
step_5: Test the cable with another device to confirm the cable is not faulty.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: High ping / latency spikes — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: High ping / latency spikes. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Slow Internet / Low Bandwidth Issues.
cause: Bandwidth congestion, ISP throttling, interference, or hardware limits.
step_1: Run an internet speed test (speedtest.net) to measure download/upload and ping.
step_2: Restart router and modem, and disconnect any heavy-usage devices.
step_3: Move closer to Wi‑Fi or use Ethernet to check if wireless is the bottleneck.
step_4: Check for scheduled tasks or background updates using Task Manager that may consume bandwidth.
step_5: If ISP throttling suspected, contact ISP or try VPN to compare speeds.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: High ping / latency spikes - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.

user_error_text: Modem offline — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Modem offline. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).
step_5: Update router firmware from the vendor's official site if available.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Modem offline - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Ethernet adapter not showing' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Ethernet adapter not showing. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Network Adapter / Driver Errors.
cause: Network adapter driver missing, corrupted, or device disabled in OS.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for the network adapter; enable it if disabled.
step_2: Right-click adapter → Uninstall device, then reboot to let Windows reinstall the driver.
step_3: Download the latest driver from the manufacturer and install it.
step_4: Check Windows Airplane mode toggle and make sure it's off.
step_5: If adapter missing, try using a USB Wi‑Fi dongle or external adapter to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Ethernet adapter not showing - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'Incorrect ISP configuration' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: Incorrect ISP configuration. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: ISP Outages & External Issues.
cause: External outage or service degradation from ISP side.
step_1: Check ISP outage map or contact ISP to confirm known outages in your area.
step_2: Restart the modem and router, and verify WAN/DSL lights are active.
step_3: If using fiber/DSL, check physical line connections and ONT status.
step_4: Use mobile data tethering to confirm whether local network or ISP is at fault.
step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Incorrect ISP configuration - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Incorrect Wi-Fi password' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Incorrect Wi-Fi password. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Incorrect Wi-Fi password - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

symptoms: Network issue: Router not giving IP. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'No internet due to ISP outage' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: No internet due to ISP outage. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: ISP Outages & External Issues.
cause: External outage or service degradation from ISP side.
step_1: Check ISP outage map or contact ISP to confirm known outages in your area.
step_2: Restart the modem and router, and verify WAN/DSL lights are active.
step_3: If using fiber/DSL, check physical line connections and ONT status.
step_4: Use mobile data tethering to confirm whether local network or ISP is at fault.
step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: No internet due to ISP outage - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

step_3: If using fiber/DSL, check physical line connections and ONT status.
step_4: Use mobile data tethering to confirm whether local network or ISP is at fault.
step_5: Document outage times and contact ISP support if problem persists.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Incorrect ISP configuration - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Wi-Fi authentication error. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Wi-Fi authentication error. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Wi-Fi authentication error - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'Wi-Fi connected but no internet' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: Wi-Fi connected but no internet. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Wi-Fi / Wireless Connection Errors.
cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Wi-Fi connected but no internet - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: I get 'LAN port not working' when I try to open websites.
symptoms: Network issue: LAN port not working. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Ethernet (LAN Cable) Connection Errors.
cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.
step_1: Ensure Ethernet cable is securely plugged in and test with a different cable.
step_2: Try a different LAN port on the router/switch to rule out port failure.
step_3: Check adapter link speed in Network Connections and set to auto-negotiate.
step_4: Update NIC drivers and disable energy-saving features that may drop the link.
step_5: Test the cable with another device to confirm the cable is not faulty.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: LAN port not working - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Ethernet (LAN Cable) Connection Errors.
cause: Cable/port fault or NIC misconfiguration causing link failures.
step_1: Ensure Ethernet cable is securely plugged in and test with a different cable.
step_2: Try a different LAN port on the router/switch to rule out port failure.
step_3: Check adapter link speed in Network Connections and set to auto-negotiate.
step_4: Update NIC drivers and disable energy-saving features that may drop the link.
step_5: Test the cable with another device to confirm the cable is not faulty.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Speed stuck at 10/100 Mbps - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'No Valid IP Configuration' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: No Valid IP Configuration. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: IP Address & DHCP Errors.
cause: DHCP server or router failed to assign an IP; adapter may have static/misconfigured settings.
step_1: Run `ipconfig /release` and `ipconfig /renew` to request a new IP from DHCP.
step_2: Check that DHCP is enabled on your router and that your adapter is set to obtain IP automatically.
step_3: Disable any static IP settings temporarily to test dynamic addressing.
step_4: Try connecting via Ethernet to see if wired connection gets a valid IP.
step_5: Restart router and the device to reinitialize DHCP leases.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: No Valid IP Configuration - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Can't browse, error: Airplane mode stuck ON. Other devices are fine.
symptoms: Network issue: Airplane mode stuck ON. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Network Adapter / Driver Errors.
cause: Network adapter driver missing, corrupted, or device disabled in OS.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for the network adapter; enable it if disabled.
step_2: Right-click adapter → Uninstall device, then reboot to let Windows reinstall the driver.
step_3: Download the latest driver from the manufacturer and install it.
step_4: Check Windows Airplane mode toggle and make sure it's off.
step_5: If adapter missing, try using a USB Wi‑Fi dongle or external adapter to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Airplane mode stuck ON - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: High ping / latency spikes.
symptoms: Network issue: High ping / latency spikes. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Slow Internet / Low Bandwidth Issues.
cause: Bandwidth congestion, ISP throttling, interference, or hardware limits.
step_1: Run an internet speed test (speedtest.net) to measure download/upload and ping.
step_2: Restart router and modem, and disconnect any heavy-usage devices.
step_3: Move closer to Wi‑Fi or use Ethernet to check if wireless is the bottleneck.
step_4: Check for scheduled tasks or background updates using Task Manager that may consume bandwidth.
step_5: If ISP throttling suspected, contact ISP or try VPN to compare speeds.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: High ping / latency spikes - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

error_name: DNS address could not be found
user_error_text: DNS address could not be found — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: DNS address could not be found. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: DNS (Domain Name System) Errors.
cause: DNS resolver misconfiguration or DNS server unresponsive.
step_1: Open Command Prompt and run `ipconfig /flushdns` to clear DNS cache.
step_2: Set DNS manually to Google DNS (8.8.8.8 / 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) and retry.
step_3: Restart your router to refresh DNS settings from ISP.
step_4: Check if other devices can resolve websites to isolate device vs network DNS issue.
step_5: If DNS server is provided by ISP and failing, contact ISP for resolution.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: DNS address could not be found - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: Frequent router restarts — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: Frequent router restarts. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).
step_5: Update router firmware from the vendor's official site if available.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Frequent router restarts - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: Firewall blocking internet access.
symptoms: Network issue: Firewall blocking internet access. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.

category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading
user_error_text: ERR_CONNECTION_TIMED_OUT — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: ERR_CONNECTION_TIMED_OUT. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading.
cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.
step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.
step_3: Ping a website (ping google.com) to test connectivity and traceroute to identify block points.
step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.
step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: ERR_CONNECTION_TIMED_OUT - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
step_5: If problem persists, test with another device to determine if issue is the router or your device.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Wi-Fi connected but no internet - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: My PC reports 'ERR_TUNNEL_CONNECTION_FAILED' and I don't know how to fix it.
symptoms: Network issue: ERR_TUNNEL_CONNECTION_FAILED. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: VPN / Proxy / Firewall Conflicts.
cause: VPN/proxy/firewall interfering with routing or DNS resolution.
step_1: Disconnect from the VPN and check if internet works without it.
step_2: Check VPN settings and try a different protocol (OpenVPN/UDP vs TCP).
step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.
step_4: Restart the VPN client and ensure the client is up to date.
step_5: If VPN breaks all traffic, contact VPN provider or switch servers to test.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: ERR_TUNNEL_CONNECTION_FAILED - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading
user_error_text: SSL certificate errors — my device shows connected but nothing loads.
symptoms: Network issue: SSL certificate errors. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Internet Access but Websites Not Loading.
cause: Protocol/blocking issue: proxy, browser settings, or SSL errors preventing site loads.
step_1: Try a different browser and clear the browser cache and cookies.
step_2: Disable proxy settings in browser and Windows (Settings → Proxy) and retry.
step_3: Ping a website (ping google.com) to test connectivity and traceroute to identify block points.
step_4: Check system date/time and SSL settings if seeing certificate errors.
step_5: Temporarily disable antivirus/firewall to test whether they block web access.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: SSL certificate errors - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: Modem offline.
symptoms: Network issue: Modem offline. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Router / Modem Related Errors.
cause: Router/modem hardware or configuration issue causing local network instability.
step_1: Power cycle the router and modem (unplug 30s, plug back in).
step_2: Check router LEDs for WAN/link activity and ensure cables are connected.
step_3: Log into router admin page and review WAN status and DHCP settings.
step_4: Reset router to factory defaults if misconfiguration suspected (backup settings first).
step_5: Update router firmware from the vendor's official site if available.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Modem offline - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

user_error_text: After last router reboot I now see: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed.
symptoms: Network issue: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed. Symptoms: no/slow browsing, timeouts, or adapter errors. Category: Slow Internet / Low Bandwidth Issues.
cause: Bandwidth congestion, ISP throttling, interference, or hardware limits.
step_1: Run an internet speed test (speedtest.net) to measure download/upload and ping.
step_2: Restart router and modem, and disconnect any heavy-usage devices.
step_3: Move closer to Wi‑Fi or use Ethernet to check if wireless is the bottleneck.
step_4: Check for scheduled tasks or background updates using Task Manager that may consume bandwidth.
step_5: If ISP throttling suspected, contact ISP or try VPN to compare speeds.
verification: Device can successfully browse websites and ping external hosts without errors.
log_snippet: Slow Wi-Fi / slow download speed - Network diagnostic entry recorded.

step_3: Disable proxy settings and check firewall rules that may block VPN traffic.

cause: Local wireless issue: wrong password, AP/SSID mismatch, weak signal, or interference.
step_1: Turn Wi‑Fi off and on on your device, then reconnect to the network and re-enter the password.
step_2: Restart your router and modem; wait 60 seconds and try again.
step_3: Move closer to the router to check for weak signal issues or interference.
step_4: Forget the network on your device and re-add it (Settings → Wi‑Fi → Forget).
